bibl.title: Troglodites and Trogodites. Exploring Interaction on the Red Sea during the Roman Period.
bibl.note: The fragmentary O. Quseir Inv. 543 [ed.: Roberta TOMBER, Amphorae from the Red Sea and their Contribution to the Interpretation of Late Roman Trade beyond the Empire, Transport, Amphorae and Trade in the Eastern Mediterranean = Monographs of the Danish Institute at Athens. 5 (Athens, 2004) pp. 393-402, figg.] mentions the term 'Trogodite'. Given the flow of goods throughout the Red Sea, the evidence (esp. the ceramics) suggests that the man may have originated from Eritrea or Ethiopia as much as from Somalia.

bibl.title: People of the Red Sea. Proceedings of Red Sea Project II Held in the British Museum, October 2004

bibl.seg: TOMBER Roberta, Troglodites and Trogodites. Exploring Interaction on the Red Sea during the Roman Period.

Janet C.M. STARKEY (Ed.), People of the Red Sea. Proceedings of Red Sea Project II Held in the British Museum, October 2004 = Society for Arabian Studies Monographs. 3 = BAR International Series. 1395 (Oxford, 2005) pp. 41-49, 3 figg., 1 carte.

The fragmentary O. Quseir Inv. 543 [ed.: Roberta TOMBER, Amphorae from the Red Sea and their Contribution to the Interpretation of Late Roman Trade beyond the Empire, Transport, Amphorae and Trade in the Eastern Mediterranean = Monographs of the Danish Institute at Athens. 5 (Athens, 2004) pp. 393-402, figg.] mentions the term 'Trogodite'. Given the flow of goods throughout the Red Sea, the evidence (esp. the ceramics) suggests that the man may have originated from Eritrea or Ethiopia as much as from Somalia.
